Selectivity to decanal was higher than 99%. c The sample was recovered in the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol at 275 °C for 68 h in ​Fig. 9​. Vapor-phase dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal over Cu/SiO2 catalyst prepared by organic additives-assisted impregnation Shuya Hosaka Data curation Visualization Writing – original draft Enggah Kurniawan Visualization Writing – review & editing Yasuhiro Yamada Supervision Validation Satoshi Sato Conceptualization Project administration Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing ⁎ Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Chiba 263-8522, Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University Chiba 263-8522 Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Chiba, 263–8522, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Silica-supported copper (Cu/SiO2) catalysts were prepared by impregnation assisted with organic additives and employed as an efficient catalyst for oxidant-free vapor-phase dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal. The XRD, N2O titration, and TEM analyses showed that the utilization of organic additives generated Cu/SiO2 catalysts with better Cu dispersion and smaller particle sizes, which led to a significantly larger Cu surface area than the Cu catalyst prepared without organic additives. Among several additives-assisted Cu/SiO2 catalysts tested, the Cu/SiO2 assisted with the 12-crown-4-ether (12C4) gave the highest catalytic performance for dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal. Compared to the unassisted Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the Cu catalyst prepared with 12C4 had a higher formation rate with significantly better long-run performance. The dehydrogenation activity, i.e. the formation rate of decanal, was simply proportional to the copper surface area of catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Dehydrogenation 1-Decanol Decanal Cu/SiO2 catalyst Organic additive Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Catalytic conversion of alcohols to their corresponding aldehydes or ketones is among essential organic transformations [1–5], and it aligns with the effort to upgrade biomass into various fine chemicals [5–7]. Oxidative and oxidant-free dehydrogenation are common strategies to convert alcohols into aldehydes or ketones [8]. The latter strategy has attracted numerous attention due to its atom-efficient nature [9–14], and with the absence of oxidants, such as O2 gas, this process is tolerant toward functional groups that are sensitive to O2 [4]. Furthermore, with hydrogen gas generated as the side product, oxidant-free dehydrogenation of alcohol could be viewed as a green and sustainable alternative for hydrogen fuel production, using organic compounds as the hydrogen source [14–17]. Liquid-phase oxidant-free dehydrogenation over precious metals, e.g., Ru [18–20], Pd [12,16,21], Pt [6,7], and Au [1,15], and non-precious metals, e.g., Co [8], Cu [13,22–25], and Ag [4,26–28], has been extensively studied. In general, the dehydrogenation of secondary aromatic alcohols over these catalysts proceeded more efficiently than that of primary aliphatic alcohol. The dehydrogenation of long primary aliphatic alcohol, in particular, has been known to be a challenging transformation due to the relative stability of this alcohol. Even though numerous catalysts have shown outstanding catalytic performance for secondary alcohols, the same catalyst often produces a small yield of aldehyde for dehydrogenation of long primary aliphatic alcohol [29]. From an environmental and industrial perspective, a continuous vapor-phase dehydrogenation of long primary aliphatic alcohol is preferable to a liquid-phase dehydrogenation. Previously, we have reported that silica-supported copper (Cu/SiO2) acts as an efficient catalyst for dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal [30]. Similarly, Kamaraju et al. have shown that supported Cu catalysts are active for 1-decanol dehydrogenation to generate decanal using CO2 as a soft oxidant [31]. Efficient vapor-phase dehydrogenation of short-chain primary alcohols such as methanol [32] and 1-butanol [24,33] is also carried out over Cu-catalysts. These reports showcase the promising activity of Cu-based catalysts for vapor-phase dehydrogenation of primary alcohols. Numerous efforts have been dedicated to improving the catalytic performance of supported metal catalysts. Previous studies have shown that the improvement of the catalytic performance is strongly correlated to metal dispersion and particle size [34–37]. Several preparation strategies of Cu-silica catalysts have been developed to generate highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles. For example, efficient Cu/SiO2 catalysts containing highly dispersed Cu species have been prepared via precipitation-gel [38], deposition-precipitation [39,40], ammonia evaporation [41–44], and impregnation on ethanolamine-modified silica [45]. We have also reported a strategy to obtain a highly dispersed catalyst with a small particle size through preparation assisted with an organic additive of citric acid [46–48]. This protocol has been proven to generate Ni-based catalysts with a significantly better catalytic performance than the conventional impregnation procedure without citric acid for hydrogenation of CO2 [46], levulinic acid [47], and acetoin [48]. In this study, we reported dehydrogenation of a long-chain aliphatic alcohol, 1-decanol, to decanal ( Scheme 1) over Cu/SiO2 catalyst prepared by an impregnation method assisted with organic additives ( Fig. 1). The addition of the organic additive significantly improved the Cu dispersion and generated Cu catalyst with small particle sizes. Furthermore, the addition of organic additives improved the catalytic performance without altering the high selectivity to decanal; thus, the high Cu dispersion and the small particle size did not facilitate the side reactions. This simple strategy could serve as a promising alternative to generate a catalyst for oxidant-free dehydrogenation of a long aliphatic primary alcohol to its corresponding aldehyde using abundant and inexpensive Cu-based catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Crown ethers such as 12-crown-4-ether (abbreviated as 12C4), 15-crown-5-ether (15C5), 18-crown-6-ether (18C6), and triethylene glycol (TEG) were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industries Co., Ltd, Japan. Citric acid (CA) and Cu(NO3)2·3H2O were purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd., Japan. Silica-supported copper (Cu/SiO2) catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method using an aqueous solution containing a prescribed amount of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and an organic additive: the molar ratio of an organic additive to the metal is 1. The solution was dropped onto a SiO2 support, which was supplied by Fuji Silysia Chemical Ltd., Japan. (CARiACT Q6 with a granule size of 75–500 µm and a specific surface area (SA) of 451 m2 g−1), and the water of the dropped solution was evaporated by illuminating the support with a 350-W electric light bulb at the support surface temperature of ca. 70 °C, this process was repeated until all the metal precursor solution had been added completely. The resulted sample was dried at 110 °C for 12 h and calcined at 300 °C for 3 h to obtain a CuO/SiO2 sample. Prior to the catalytic reaction and characterization, the resulted CuO/SiO2 sample was reduced in H2 flow at 300 °C for 1 h to prepare Cu/SiO2. The resulting catalyst is expressed as A-xCu/SiO2, where A and x indicate the used organic additive and the weight percent of the metal, respectively. 2.2 Characterization The thermogravimetry-differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) was recorded on Thermoplus 8120E2 (Rigaku) under the heating conditions in the air with a temperature range of 110–900 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1: the sample of ca. 7 mg was heated from a room temperature to 110 °C, held for 1 h to remove surface water adsorbed on the catalyst, and then heated to 900 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples were recorded on a D8 ADVANCE (Bruker, Japan) using Cu Kα radiation. A crystallite size was estimated from XRD peak broadening of a main peak using Scherrer’s equation, which was described in the supporting information. For the characterization of the reduction behavior of the unreduced catalyst, temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was performed under the conditions: a sample of 30 mg was heated in a mixed gas of H2/N2 (=1/9) with the flow rate of 10 cm3 min−1 from a room temperature to 900 °C with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. High-resolution field emission transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were observed on a Hitachi HF-2200 microscope operated at 200 kV. The Cu dispersion (D) and the Cu surface area (SA Cu) were determined using N2O oxidation followed by TPR titration (N2O titration) described in a previous literature [49]. The details of the procedure of N2O titration are described in the supporting information. 2.3 Catalytic test The vapor-phase catalytic dehydrogenation of 1-decanol, which was purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd., Japan, was performed in a fixed-bed flow reactor at atmospheric pressure of N2. The catalyst was loaded into the reactor and reduced with H2 gas at 300 °C for 1 h. Thereafter, 1-decanol was fed through the reactor top at a liquid feed rate of 1.7 g h−1 together with an N2 flow of 1.8 dm3 h−1 at 275 °C for the time on stream (TOS) of 5 h. The reaction effluents were collected in an ice-water trap every hour. The recovered products were identified using a gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a mass-spectrometer (QP5050A, Shimadzu Corp.) and a capillary column (DB-WAX, a length of 30 m, JW Scientific). They were quantitatively analyzed by a GC (GC-8A, Shimadzu) equipped with a flame ionization detector and a 30-m capillary column of Inert Cap 1 (inner diameter of 0.53 mm and a length of 30 m, GL-Sciences Inc.) using 1-hexanol as an internal standard. Another off-line GC equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (GC-8A, Shimadzu) and a 6-m packed column (VZ-7, GL-Sciences) using a gas-tight injection syringe to analyze gaseous products: no gaseous products such as carbon monoxide, methane, and C2-C4 hydrocarbons were detected in the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol. The formation rate of decanal (R decanal) is defined as the following equation where the 1-decanol conversion less than 30% was used for the calculation: R decanal ( g decanal g cat . − 1 h − 1 ) = 1.66 ( g − 1 h − 1 ) × conv . × selet . 100 × cat . weight ( g ) 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of organic additives on the property of the resulted Cu/SiO2 catalysts Table 1 displays the effect of several organic additives during the preparation of Cu/SiO2 catalyst on its activity for dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal. None-10Cu/SiO2 catalyst prepared without any organic additives was active to some extent for the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol (Entry 1). The effect of additives on the catalytic activity was remarkable: the addition of organic additives such as 12C4, 15C5, 18C6, CA, and TEG during catalyst preparation significantly enhanced the catalytic performance of 10Cu/SiO2 catalyst (Entries 2–5). The SA Cu and D of Cu/SiO2 catalysts listed in Table 1 were calculated by N2O titration. Notably, the SA Cu and D of Cu/SiO2 catalysts prepared by organic additives were higher than the none-Cu/SiO2 catalyst. Concurrently, the improvement of the catalytic activity of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts prepared with additives was related to the increment of their SA Cu and D. Therefore, it could be assumed that the utilization of organic additives during catalyst preparation generated Cu/SiO2 catalysts with larger SA Cu and D. Since 12C4-, 15C5-, and TEG-10Cu/SiO2 catalysts possessed the highest SA Cu and D, these catalysts provided the highest catalytic activity among the 10Cu/SiO2 catalysts tested. The efficiency of 12C4 in generating the Cu/SiO2 catalyst that contains highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles might be due to the relative stability of the Cu2+ complex formed between Cu2+ and 12C4 as a ligand. It has been reported that the stability of the complex between metal cations and crown ether ligands is strongly correlated to size adequacy: the complex is generally stable when the cation radii are close to the cavity radius of the crown ethers [50]. The ionic radius of Cu2+ was reported to be 0.73 Å, while the cavity radii of 12C4, 15C5, and 18C6 were 0.6–0.75, 0.85–1.1, and 1.3–1.6 Å, respectively [51]. Therefore, it is reasonable that 12C4 formed a more stable complex with Cu2+ than with 15C5 or 18C6, leading to a formation of an efficient Cu/SiO2 catalyst. TEG, which has a structure similar to 12C4 (Fig. 1), might also form a relatively stable complex with Cu2+. Nevertheless, the open structure of TEG might slightly influence the stability of the Cu2+-TEG complex; thus, the obtained Cu/SiO2 catalyst gave slightly lower efficiency than the Cu/SiO2 catalysts prepared with 12C4 and 15C5. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of several 10Cu/SiO2 catalysts prepared with and without organic additives. The peaks located at 35.5°, 38.7°, and 48.7° are indexed to CuO phase of (002), (111), and (202) planes, respectively [52–54]. The intensity of these CuO peaks significantly weakened for all the 10Cu/SiO2 catalysts prepared with the addition of organic additives. Previous reports have suggested that the decrement in the peak intensity could be attributed to a higher dispersion of CuO species and the presence of CuO with smaller particle sizes [42,45,55,56]. Fig. 3 shows the TEM images of 12C4- and none-10Cu/SiO2 catalysts. The TEM images clearly indicate that the 12C4–10Cu/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 3A) had a smaller particle size than that of none-10Cu/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 3B). Thus, the results from XRD analysis were in good agreement with the finding from N2O titration and TEM observation which suggest that the utilization of organic additives generated Cu/SiO2, containing highly dispersed small Cu particles. 3.2 Characterization of 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalysts Fig. 4A displays the XRD profiles of unreduced 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalysts with different Cu content. It is reasonable that increasing the Cu content increased the intensity of the CuO peaks. Nevertheless, the intensity of the CuO peaks in 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalysts was significantly smaller than that of the CuO species in none-Cu/SiO2 catalysts (Fig. 4B). These findings indicate that the dispersion of the CuO species in the 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalysts was higher than that in the none-Cu/SiO2 catalysts for all Cu contents tested [42]. Fig. 5 illustrates the TPR profiles of unreduced samples of 12C4- and none-Cu/SiO2 catalysts with different Cu content. The H2-uptake increased with the increase in Cu content. It is worth noting that the reduction peaks of the 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst are located at lower temperatures than the reduction peak of none-Cu/SiO2 catalysts. The TPR results suggest that the addition of 12C4 as an organic additive generates the Cu catalysts with more reducible CuO species than the Cu catalysts prepared without the addition of organic additives. Dong et al. have reported that the reducibility of the CuO species in the Cu/SiO2 catalyst was related to CuO dispersion: higher CuO dispersion led to more reducible CuO species [55]. Since the 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst consisted of more dispersed CuO species than the none-Cu/SiO2 catalyst (Entries 1 and 2 in Table 1), it is obvious that the CuO species in the 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst are more reducible than the one in the none-Cu/SiO2 catalyst. Fig. 4C shows the XRD patterns of 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalysts after reduction with H2 gas at 300 °C for 1 h. The peaks associated with the CuO planes disappeared and new peaks correspond to metallic Cu appeared at 43.3° (111) and 50.4° (200) [57,58]. The TPR curves (Fig. 5) show that the reduction of the CuO species in the 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalysts proceeds under 200 °C; therefore, the reduction procedure at 300 °C would be enough to reduce the CuO species into metallic Cu. Remarkably, the peak intensity of the metallic Cu in the reduced 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst was still lower than the one in the reduced none-Cu/SiO2 catalyst for all Cu contents (Fig. 4D). The average particle sizes of Cu nanoparticles, D Cu, are summarized in Table S1. The calculation clearly shows that the 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalysts consisted of Cu particles that are more dispersed and smaller than that in the none-Cu/SiO2 catalysts at the same Cu content even after the reduction treatment with H2 gas at 300 °C. Thus, the smaller peak intensity in the XRD profiles of the 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalysts than the none-Cu/SiO2 catalysts was possibly due to the presence of smaller and more dispersed Cu particles. In addition, Table S2 summarizes Cu dispersion for several Cu-silica catalysts previously reported [38–43,45]. The present D Cu values in Table S1 are generally acceptable in comparison with those reported for Cu-silica prepared by impregnation, while the estimation of Cu dispersion is discussed in SI file. Fig. 6A illustrates the effect of Cu content on the SA Cu for the Cu/SiO2 catalyst prepared with and without 12C4 addition. Generally, the SA Cu increased with the increment of Cu content. However, the addition of 12C4 was proven to generate Cu-catalyst with a significantly larger SA Cu. It is worth noting that the SA Cu of none-Cu/SiO2 catalyst with 20 wt.-% of Cu was smaller than those of 10 and 15 wt.-%. The increment of the Cu content from 15 to 20 wt.-% in the none-Cu/SiO2 catalyst probably caused the aggregation of CuO particles, which led to a decrement of SA Cu. Remarkably, no decrement was observed in the same Cu range of 12C4–20Cu/SiO2 catalyst. This finding indicates that small CuO particles were highly dispersed onto SiO2 support even at the highest Cu content of 20 wt.-%, as indicated by XRD patterns (Fig. 4 A and C). 3.3 Effect of organic additives on the formation rate of decanal Fig. 6A also depicts the correlation between the formation rate of decanal per gram catalyst and the Cu content for 12C4- and none-Cu/SiO2 catalysts. The formation rate increased as the Cu content increased from 2 to 20 wt.-%, except for none-20Cu/SiO2 catalyst. Notably, 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalysts provided higher formation rates than none-Cu/SiO2 catalysts. The 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalysts, which contain highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles with higher SA Cu, might facilitate more efficient dehydrogenation than none-Cu/SiO2 catalysts. It is worth noting that the changes in the formation rate are comparable to the changes in SA Cu with Cu content (Fig. 6A). The lower activity of none-20Cu/SiO2 catalyst compared to none-15Cu/SiO2 was strongly correlated with their respective SA Cu: none-20Cu/SiO2 has lower SA Cu than none-15Cu/SiO2 catalyst. Fig. 6B illustrates the correlation between the SACu metal surface area of Cu/SiO2 catalysts and the formation rate of decanal. The results are quite simple: the formation rate is proportional to SA Cu for all the Cu/SiO2 catalysts with good linearity. In addition, the formation rate of decanal over 15C5-, 18C6-, CA-, and TEG-10Cu/SiO2 catalysts was also correlated with their SA Cu. Several reports have also shown a similar linear correlation between SA Cu and the catalytic activity of Cu catalysts in the dehydrogenation of diols [59] and CO2 hydrogenation [60]. Therefore, our findings strongly suggested that the utilization of organic additives to improve the catalytic properties such as D, particle size, and SA Cu positively affected the catalytic performance of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst in the present oxidant-free dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal. 3.4 Effect of reaction temperature and contact time Fig. 7A depicts the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic activity of the 12C4–10Cu/SiO2 catalysts at a low contact time, W/F, of 0.012 h. The initial activity of the 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst increased with the increment of reaction temperature. However, high reaction temperature led to a severe catalyst deactivation. The reaction temperature of 275 °C provided the most optimum condition for dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal over 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst among several reaction temperatures tested. The 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst was relatively more stable at 275 °C despite having lower initial activity compared to 300 °C. Intriguingly, the 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst seems to have lower activity at 325 °C than that at 275 and 300 °C. The intrinsic conversion of the Cu catalyst at 325 °C was possibly the highest among several temperatures tested, however, due to a significantly severe catalyst deactivation the conversion at TOS of 0 – 1 h was lower than the reaction temperature of 275 and 300 °C. A similar phenomenon of severe deactivation at high temperature was observed when none-10Cu/SiO2 catalyst was employed for dehydrogenation of 1-decanol [30]. From these findings, it can be said that moderate reaction temperature of 275 °C provided the most conducive conditions for 1-decanol dehydrogenation. Fig. 7B reveals the effect of contact time, W/F, on the catalytic activity of the 12C4- and none-Cu/SiO2 catalysts. Significant increment of decanal yield was observed when the contact time was increased up to 0.4 h, with no significant increment afterwards. The slight decrement of decanal yield at W/F higher than 0.4 h was due to the decrement of decanal selectivity: by-products such as decyl decanoate, 1-decene, and dodecyl ether were observed. It is worth noting that the selectivity to the by-products was less than 10%, even at the longest W/F. It has been reported that the utilization of SiO2 was superior to other supports, such as alumina and zirconia, in the dehydrogenation of ethanol since these supports promote dehydration and esterification, respectively [61]. Combining this SiO2 behavior with the generation of highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles from organic-assisted impregnation generated Cu/SiO2 catalyst with superior activity. Notably, the 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst generated a higher decanal yield with a shorter contact time than the none-Cu/SiO2 catalyst. Prolonging the contact time did not improve the yield of decanal at a N2 flow rate of 30 cm3 min−1 since the reaction had reached the equilibrium, as shown in Fig. 7B. Fig. 8 depicts the effect of varying the N2 flow rate on the production of decanal to show the effect of the partial pressure of 1-decanol. Clearly, the increment of N2 flow rate increased the yield of decanal at 275 °C and W/F= 0.59 h. Considering the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal is an equilibrium reaction, the constant of equilibrium (K p) at a given temperature can be expressed by the following equation: K p = P decanal × P H 2 P 1 − decanol According to the above equation, the decrement of the partial pressure of the system could promote the consumption of 1-decanol and the formation of decanal since the K p at a given temperature should be constant. Therefore, increasing the flow rate of N2 gas reduced the partial pressure of the system, which consequently shifted the equilibrium yield towards the product, leading to a higher yield of decanal in Fig. 8. Furthermore, the K p values for each N2 flow rate at 275 °C were regarded to be a constant of ca. 0.44, which confirmed the above assumption. The highest decanal yield of 90.8% could be attained in an N2 flow of 90 cm3 min−1 at a reaction temperature of 275 °C. 3.5 Long-run performance of the 12C4-10Cu/SiO2 catalyst The long-run performance of 12C4- and none-10Cu/SiO2 catalysts was investigated by the TOS at which its conversion drops to 60% (t 60). Fig. 9 depicts the long-run performance of the 12C4–10Cu/SiO2 catalyst compared to the none-10Cu/SiO2 catalyst: the t 60 for the 12C4–10Cu/SiO2 and the none-10Cu/SiO2 catalyst were 68 and 28 h, respectively. This result shows that the addition of 12C4 during catalyst preparation prolonged the t 60 by more than 2.3 times. The weight loss in the TG curve (Fig. S3) indicates the presence of carbon deposited on the used catalyst. The amounts of carbon deposited on the catalyst are 10.0, 12.7, and 14.2 wt.-% after the reaction at TOS of 0.5, 5, and 68 h (Fig. S3A). The carbon deposition was severe in the initial stage of the reaction at a TOS of 0.5 h and the carbon deposition proceeds gradually afterward. The carbon deposit of 14.2 wt.-% for 68 h is quite the same as that of none-Cu/SiO2 catalyst for 28 h: carbon amount was 14.2 wt.-% (Fig. S3B). From this finding, it is reasonable to assume that both 12C4- and none-Cu/SiO2 catalysts might have the same deactivation rate; however, since 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst had significantly higher intrinsic activity, i.e., formation rate, this catalyst could perform longer than that of none-Cu/SiO2 which had lower intrinsic activity. Fig. 3C shows the TEM image of the spent 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst after the long run test (Fig. 9). The TEM image indicates the size of Cu particles after the reaction at 275 °C for 68 h is similar to that of the fresh one in Fig. 3A, suggesting no significant agglomeration occurred during the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol. Nevertheless, the catalytic performance of the 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst decreased, as shown in Fig. 9. These findings indicate that agglomeration of Cu nanoparticles is not the main cause of the catalyst deactivation. Although the gradual decrement of the conversion in Fig. 9 seems to be caused by the gradual carbon deposition (Fig. S3A), the change in the catalyst structure might also contribute to the catalyst deactivation. The XRD analysis of the spent 12C4- and none-10Cu/SiO2 catalysts was performed to clarify the change in the crystallite structure of the catalysts. Fig. 10 depicts the XRD profiles of the spent 12C4- and none-Cu/SiO2 catalysts. A diffraction peak attributed to Cu2O was observed (Fig. 10A) in the spent none-Cu/SiO2 catalyst, while the diffraction associated with Cu2O was less visible in the spent 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst. Table 2 summarizes the formation rate of decanal in the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol over spent 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalysts after being regenerated through several processes. The spent 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst without any pre-treatments gave a low formation rate (Entry 2). The oxidation of carbonaceous species by calcination in air at several temperatures was effective for the regeneration of the spent catalyst, especially the calcination at 550 °C (Entry 4). Furthermore, the reduction of the spent catalyst at 300 °C without any prior calcination was also efficient in recovering the performance of the spent 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst (Entry 3). Therefore, surface Cu oxidation during the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol was the major reason for the catalyst deactivation. A similar method to recover the dehydrogenation activity of Cu/SiO2 catalyst has also been reported [30]: the removal of deposited carbon by calcination at 400 °C followed by reduction at 300 °C recovers the activity of Cu/SiO2 catalyst. In summary, oxidant-free dehydrogenation of 1-decanol was successfully carried out over 12C4-Cu/SiO2 catalyst. The utilization of organic additive had been proven to generate Cu catalyst with small particle sizes and improved the D and SA Cu, which consecutively enhanced the catalytic performance of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst. This work offers a simple strategy to enhance the catalytic performance of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst for oxidant-free dehydrogenation of long-chain primary aliphatic alcohol, which has been known to be less active than secondary and aromatic alcohol. 4 Conclusion The addition of organic additive during the preparation of Cu/SiO2 catalyst by an impregnation method improved the catalytic activity and long-run performance of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst in oxidant-free dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal. The improvement of the catalytic performance was related to the generation of highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles on SiO2 support, which led to a substantial improvement of Cu metal surface area. The formation rate of decanal in the dehydrogenation of 1-decanol was found to be simply proportional to the Cu metal surface area. This organic additives-assisted impregnation method could be considered to be an efficient strategy to enhance the catalytic activity of Cu catalyst in the dehydrogenation of a long aliphatic primary alcohol which has been known to be less active than the short-chain and benzylic primary alcohol and secondary alcohol. coredata.dc:description: Silica-supported copper (Cu/SiO2) catalysts were prepared by impregnation assisted with organic additives and employed as an efficient catalyst for oxidant-free vapor-phase dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal. The XRD, N2O titration, and TEM analyses showed that the utilization of organic additives generated Cu/SiO2 catalysts with better Cu dispersion and smaller particle sizes, which led to a significantly larger Cu surface area than the Cu catalyst prepared without organic additives. Among several additives-assisted Cu/SiO2 catalysts tested, the Cu/SiO2 assisted with the 12-crown-4-ether (12C4) gave the highest catalytic performance for dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal. Compared to the unassisted Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the Cu catalyst prepared with 12C4 had a higher formation rate with significantly better long-run performance. The dehydrogenation activity, i.e. the formation rate of decanal, was simply proportional to the copper surface area of catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Vapor-phase dehydrogenation of 1-decanol to decanal over Cu/SiO2 catalyst prepared by organic additives-assisted impregnation
